story:
Mein Gefairt

Ich heiße Wiebke Nauber und habe bisher hauptberuflich Kinder- und Jugendarbeit in der evangelischen Kirche gemacht, die letzen 14 Jahre in Gruiten, einem kleinen Ort zwischen Wuppertal und Düsseldorf. Immer wieder begegnete mir beruflichlich und privat das Thema Gerechtigkeit und fairer Handel. Und immer wieder hörte und dachte ich: "Wir müssten viel mehr dafür tun können."

Ich stellte fest, wie schwierig es ist, in unserer Region faire Kleidung zu kaufen, wenn man sie nicht im Internet bestellen will. Und ich hörte immer wieder, wie sich Menschen darüber ärgerten, zum Kauf von fairer Kleidung aufgefordert zu werden, das auch einzusehen, es aber kaum umsetzen zu können.

So kam mir der Gedanke: Ich möchte, dass mehr Menschen sich mit diesem Thema auseinandersetzen, dann aber nicht an der Umsetzung scheitern.  Und es entstand die Idee, einen LKW oder Bus umzubauen in einen mobilen Laden für fair gehandelte Kleidung.

Ich habe sehr viele Kontakte zu Menschen und Einrichtungen im Raum der Kirche. Diese möchte ich nutzen. Auch Verbindungen zu meinem bisherigen Beruf können mir weiterhelfen: Zu einem theoretischen Vortrag bringe ich die praktische Umsetzung gleich mit. Erst die Theorie, dann das Shoppen.

Es gibt viele Weltläden in der näheren Umgebung, die Interesse daran haben werden, mich in regelmäßigen Abständen mit dem Gefairt einzuladen und so zumindest z.B. einmal pro Monat auch Kleidung anbieten zu können.

Auf der Messe "Innatex" 2016 verschaffte ich mir einen Überblick über das Angebot von fairer Kleidung. Es gibt tolle, coole, schöne, langlebige und bezahlbare Mode. Aktuelle wie zeitlose, für Junge und Alte... Kurz: Ich war begeistert und entschlossen, meinen Traum zu realisieren.

Im Dezember entdeckte mein Mann dann einen  Iveco daily (DHL-Fahrzeug aus den Niederlanden, 6,5 Tonnen, siehe Foto). Dieser hat einen großen Ladeaufbau (5,12*2,20m) und lässt sich hervorragend umbauen. Wir kauften kurzerhand einen solchen. "Mehr, als dass wir ihn wieder verkaufen müssen, kann ja nicht passieren", sagten wir uns.

    Die Finanzierung

    Momentan stecke ich im mühsamen Vorlauf. Ein Kredit für's Gröbste muss her, damit nichts schief geht. Das zieht sich gerade extrem in die Länge. Wenn ich den angepeilten Betrag bekomme, ist das Gefairt startbereit. Mehr aber auch nicht. Es wäre von außen so beklebt und lackiert, dass es nicht mehr nach DHL aussieht. Mein Sortiment wäre recht überschaubar, da ich kaum Geld hätte, im Juli auf der Messe Ware vorzubestellen. Die wird dann nämlich im Januar geliefert, bei Erstbestellungen werden aber 30% Anzahlung fällig.
    Für mich selbst benötige ich auch ein kleines Gehalt. Im ersten halben Jahr hoffe ich aber noch auf eine Förderung durch die Arbeitsagentur.

    Gerne würde ich mit etwas mehr finanziellem Spielraum starten, um einiges einfach schöner, anderes entspannter, vieles auch attraktiver zu haben.

    Wenn ich mehr Geld zusammen bekomme als ich brauche, möchte ich die "Kampagne für saubere Kleidung" unterstützen. Auch der Teil des Geldes, den ich nur vorübergehend zur Vorfinanzierung der ersten Ware benötige, wird später an diese Adresse gehen.

    Nähere Informationen unter http://www.saubere-kleidung.de
     

    Jeder, der mich dabei unterstützt, gestaltet die hinteren Türen des Gefairts mit. Diese werden zum "Sponsorenfeld": Mit verschiedenfarbigen Lackstiften dürfen sich alle verewigen, die mir den Start erleichtern: Die, die mir 10 Euro oder mehr zur Verfügung stellen genauso wie die, die beim Umbau helfen. Wer nicht selber zum Unterschreiben kommen kann, wird (auf Wunsch) von mir hinzugefügt. Ab einer Unterstützung von 100 Euro bekommt ihr dazu noch einen 10%-Gutschein.

    Was mir noch wichtig ist:

    Für mich ist dieses Projekt auch Ausdruck meines Glaubens, meiner  Hoffnung auf Gott. Eines Tages wird in seinem Reich Gerechtigkeit und Friede herrschen. Das kann und soll auch heute schon sichtbar werden. Der Prophet Jesaja sagt:  "Der Gerechtigkeit Frucht wird Friede sein". Das stimmt einfach. Und weil ich daran glaube, dass Gott unsere Bemühungen um Gerechtigkeit und Frieden vollenden wird, kann und will ich handeln, auch wenn ich weiß, dass mein Beitrag winzig klein ist ("Wer hofft, kann handeln", mein Lieblingszitat von Johannes Rau, wird wie das Jesajazitat auf meinem Gefairt stehen.).

story:
Anson of Okotoks markets products made using 'green chemistry' -  earth-friendly yet cost-effective alternatives to the toxic chemicals and tree-based products currently used in business and industry.

Headquartered in Okotoks, Alberta -  one of Canada’s most environmentally-conscious communities - Anson of Okotoks serves a population of about four million including two major cities - Calgary and Edmonton.

Our business is to identify and sell green products to businesses across the province of Alberta. 

For example, we have identified a completely biodegradable sanitizer
- made from natural enzymes - that safely disinfects and deodorizes poultry operations. This solves two of the biggest challenges faced by chicken and egg farmers – reducing ammonia levels and controlling bird diseases. Tests have proven that this product significantly reduces bird deaths, promotes faster growth rates and controls pests such as darkling beetles far better than other products currently available.

Did you know that the interior of your car can be one of the most polluted environments on earth? We’ve discovered a product that  makes vehicle interiors completely odour and germ free in less than 45 minutes.  It sanitizes your vehicle's interior and kills dangerous germs that grow in it ventilation system, and it leaves your vehicle smelling as fresh as it did when it came off the assembly line.

We’ve found a company that supplies facial tissues and table napkins made primarily from sugar cane residue instead of wood pulp, and disposable knives, forks and spoons made primarily from plant starch instead of plastic. These products have exactly the same characteristics as their wood and petroleum-based alternatives. Why are they better? A sugar cane crop grows every seven months. It takes 20 years to grow a tree. And plant starch decomposes in about a year in a landfill, whereas plastic can last for a thousand years.

So you see we’ve got a lot to offer already, and we’ve just started looking.

With your support, we want to raise the $35,000 we need to get up to speed. Your contribution will be pay for product samples, web site development, promotion, advertising and help us build an inventory.

We’ve got some great thank-you gifts, including alcohol-free GFS BioProtect Hand Sanitizer, XPELTM auto deodorizer and copies of our business plan for you to start up in your area of the world. And if you kick in $7,500, we’ll give you a once-in-a-lifetime experience at fabulous Lake Louise in the Canadian Rockies.

You can also help promote the use of 'green chemistry' products by  encouraging local business owners in your area to use the, particularly since the cost of doing so will be about the same as what they’re paying now.

The more business knows about the availability of these products, the better the world will be for our children and grandchildren.

story:
Who We Are...

We are a small group of Italian women that have been working for years towards a clear objective: helping a small African community to develop. 

It all started in 1997 in Tanzania, in the little village of Utende on Mafia Island.  We spent some time with the locals, we learned their language and spoke about their issues and necessities.

"A school in Utende" was the title of our first flyer, printed at home and given to friends in order to fund our first project. 

In 2005, we registered as the volunteering association, KARIBUNI ONLUS, with the intention of always helping more people with support towards health and education. 

Karibuni means 'welcome' in Swahili. For us it means opening doors and collaborating. Our little group is growing and would hugely benefit from your contribution too. 

What We Need 

Thanks to your donations we will be able to buy enough necessities to reach our objective and help the population of Mafia Island to prevent local deaths caused by malaria and iron-deficency anemia. 

€5 (Euros) is enough to buy one mosquito net, with only €50 we can buy enough nets to save an entire house. 

Among the pregnant women and children on the Island, we also want to provide as many anemia treatments as possible.

Pregnant women (8€ each treatment)

Infants aged 6 months-2 years (8€ each treatment)

2-6 years aged children (13€ each treatment)

7-12 years aged children (15€ each treatment)

In order to cover the population of an entire district on the Island we need to raise a total of €5000.


TOTAL CHARITY GOAL  – 5000€

Your money can make a huge difference to people's lives.

The Impact

Help us prevent Malaria

One of the most successful projects for the whole of sub-sahara Africa is the distribution of mosquito nets treated with insecticide. The use of such nets highly reduces the risks of getting malaria, by simply protecting from the bites of contagious mosquitos. In the last 5 years Karibuni Onlus has distributed over 10 000 mosquito nets across the Island. Each mosquito net deteriorates in two to three years and then needs to be replaced. The project focuses on the prevention of malaria which aligns with Tanzania's national health services. Such services offer free diagnosis and cures for the whole population. 

Prevention is the missing link.

This is why our NGO is offering, on top of the mosquito nets distribution scheme, free courses for local primary school children to help them understand how the disease is contracted, transmitted and how to avoid the spreading of malaria.

   


Help us cure Anemia

Anemia is a condition characterised by a decrease in the number of red blood cells or hemoglobin, resulting in a lower ability for the blood to carry and deliver adequate oxygen to body tissues. 

Together with malaria, anemia is a major cause of disability and mortality in developing countries: every year 750.000 individuals die of anemia only in Africa and South-East of Asia. 

The disease particularly affects children and pregnant women.

In Sub-Saharan Africa, at least 50% of anemia cases are related to iron deficiency. Unlike other types of anemia, iron-deficiency anemia can efficiently be treated with a limited-costs therapy. 

The aim of our project  is to diagnose and treat iron-deficiency anemia in as many as children and pregnant women as possible. Furthermore, we will collect epidemiologic data that will help to conduct similar projects in other African regions.

Diagnosis will be made by simple blood tests and the therapy consists of the oral administration of iron, folic acid and, if necessary, other micronutrients. 

We need your help to diagnose iron-deficiency anemia and to buy iron and folic acid tablets and syrups to undergo the therapy and efficiently treat the disease on Mafia Island.


   


What You Receive

We are offering lovely Tinga Tinga pictures or special T-shirt. Tinga Tinga is a typical Tanzanian pictorial style. 

tinga tinga Pictures


Tinga Tinga T-Shirt

Other Ways You Can Help

Post about us on Facebook, Twitter, other social media outlets or wherever you think is suitable.

Organise a party, and ask your guests to donate some money to our organisation, instead of bringing two bottles of wine! 

Please get in touch with us for more information or further questions:

info@misaada.it
story_txt:
Who We Are...We are a small group of Italian women that have been working for years towards a clear objective: helping a small African community to develop. It all started in 1997 in Tanzania, in the little village of Utende on Mafia Island.  We spent some time with the locals, we learned their language and spoke about their issues and necessities."A school in Utende" was the title of our first flyer, printed at home and given to friends in order to fund our first project. In 2005, we registered as the volunteering association, KARIBUNI ONLUS, with the intention of always helping more people with support towards health and education. Karibuni means 'welcome' in Swahili. For us it means opening doors and collaborating. Our little group is growing and would hugely benefit from your contribution too. What We Need 
Thanks to your donations we will be able to buy enough necessities to reach our objective and help the population of Mafia Island to prevent local deaths caused by malaria and iron-deficency anemia. €5 (Euros) is enough to buy one mosquito net, with only €50 we can buy enough nets to save an entire house. Among the pregnant women and children on the Island, we also want to provide as many anemia treatments as possible.
Pregnant women (8€ each treatment)
Infants aged 6 months-2 years (8€ each treatment)
2-6 years aged children (13€ each treatment)
7-12 years aged children (15€ each treatment)In order to cover the population of an entire district on the Island we need to raise a total of €5000.
TOTAL CHARITY GOAL  – 5000€Your money can make a huge difference to people's lives.The Impact
Help us prevent Malaria
One of the most successful projects for the whole of sub-sahara Africa is the distribution of mosquito nets treated with insecticide. The use of such nets highly reduces the risks of getting malaria, by simply protecting from the bites of contagious mosquitos. In the last 5 years Karibuni Onlus has distributed over 10 000 mosquito nets across the Island. Each mosquito net deteriorates in two to three years and then needs to be replaced. The project focuses on the prevention of malaria which aligns with Tanzania's national health services. Such services offer free diagnosis and cures for the whole population. Prevention is the missing link.This is why our NGO is offering, on top of the mosquito nets distribution scheme, free courses for local primary school children to help them understand how the disease is contracted, transmitted and how to avoid the spreading of malaria.



   

Help us cure AnemiaAnemia is a condition characterised by a decrease in the number of red blood cells or
hemoglobin, resulting in a lower ability for the blood to carry and
deliver adequate oxygen to body tissues. 
Together with malaria, anemia is a major cause of disability and
mortality in developing countries: every year 750.000 individuals die of
anemia only in Africa and South-East of Asia. 
The disease particularly affects children and pregnant
women.
In Sub-Saharan Africa, at least 50% of anemia cases are related to
iron deficiency. Unlike other types of anemia, iron-deficiency anemia can
efficiently be treated with a limited-costs therapy. 
The aim of our project  is to diagnose and treat
iron-deficiency anemia in as many as children and pregnant women as possible.
Furthermore, we will collect epidemiologic data that will help to conduct
similar projects in other African regions.
Diagnosis will be made by simple blood tests and
the therapy consists of the oral administration of iron, folic
acid and, if necessary, other micronutrients. 
We need your help to diagnose iron-deficiency anemia and to buy
iron and folic acid tablets and syrups to undergo the therapy and
efficiently treat the disease on Mafia Island.



   



What You Receive
We are offering lovely Tinga Tinga pictures or special T-shirt. Tinga Tinga is a typical Tanzanian pictorial style. 

tinga tinga Pictures




Tinga Tinga T-Shirt




Other Ways You Can Help




Post about us on Facebook, Twitter, other social media outlets or wherever you think is suitable.
Organise a party, and ask your guests to donate some money to our organisation, instead of bringing two bottles of wine! 
Please get in touch with us for more information or further questions:
info@misaada.it

story:
What is Locals?

Locals is a socially based business which grows reliable quality organic produce in a vertical farm. We combine sensors and technology to allow for a continuous sustainable source of organic produce which is affordable.

          


Locals is an idea that grew from the current and growing demand of organic produce that is affordable, local, and transparent and our desire for corporate social responsibility. We at Locals want to end the gray deserts and alleviate the toll that factory farming has on our country by using our sustainable vertical aquaponics growing system. 

We connect you to the story behind the produce we grow while building a better world for this generation and the next. With Locals, we allow for cities to grow smart.

NET ZERO FARM means a building with zero net energy consumption, meaning the total amount of energy used by the building on an annual basis is roughly equal to the amount of renewable energy created on the site.

      Our Community Initiatives                                      

VETGRO

VETGRO's purpose is to harness current veteran’s specialized training and interest and couple with the training and coursework Locals has so that veterans can do the various essential positions in Locals.

SEED

SEED purpose is to give disadvantaged students and adults the needed skills that will allow for them to be more competitive in the work force , and potential employment opportunities in Locals.

GROLAB

GROLAB purpose is to foster  lifelong interest in stem and agricultural studies  in high school  and college student.

HAVEN

HAVEN purpose is to provide a safe haven for native species through Locals conservation efforts.

SUSTAINAGRO

SUSTAINAGRO purpose is for Locals to become a more sustainable farm with no negative impact on the environment. Locals have a mission to become a net zero farm by year five in operations and for every Locals farm launch in the future to be an net zero farm.


What is Aquaponics?

Aquaponics is a sustainable farming method that utilizes aquatic animals and plants in a symbiotic relationship. In this relationship the aquatic animal’s supplies nutrients for plants to grow and the plants in turns purify the water.

                                                  

                              



Aquaponics Compared to Traditional Agriculture

What are Food Deserts ? 

Food Desert are place where their aren't any fresh produce.

At Locals we don't believe that income or location should factor into whether or not you get healthy quality food. We want to provide people with quality organic produce regardless of income.   So we devise a  naturally efficient way to produce healthy organic produce in a affordable way. We also have partnerships we will use so that every community can have access to our produce.

Our Current System Design 


We currently have a working system design one that allows for quality organic produce and continuous monitoring. We plan on taking this system to the next level thanks to your funds and with the engineering consultant.     

        

           

What are the Benefits?

            

           Organic Produce                          No Fertilizer                  Year Round Growing 

           

          Less Crop Failure                        No Antibiotics                             No GMO's 

              

     Land Conservation           Community Development    Protects Our Waterways

                   Reliable Produce                  Energy Conservation                  Healthy Produce 

               Economic Development        Diverse of Local Produce          Any So Much More    


Where We Are 

We currently have a small scale aquaponics setup where we are currently conducting research and development, and are now ready to take what we've learned in our small scale system and bring it to commercial level.


What's Next

  1. Locals needs to consult with a commercial aquaponics system designer 
    to redesign our current small scale system to a system that can meet the demand of the public.
  2. Leasing of grow room
  3. Buying needed sensors to allow for continuous monitoring & environmental controls
  4. Building the first line of prototypes
  5. Purchase of fish, seeds and other materials needed for an aquaponics system
  6. Grow our produce

Why We Need You

We are seeking funding to take Locals to the next stage. The funds will be allocated to the startup projects Locals needs to conduct in order to take Locals from an idea to a scalable business. Every donation is important to us as it helps us get one step closer to our goal of launching a successful company.  Once launched we will be able to provide quality organic produce for the masses at affordable prices! All together we can launch Locals!


Our Team 

We are a group of foodies that share a passion for farming, giving back, and technology. After learning about our food system, we realized something was missing. So we set out to transform how we believe farming and business should be done in this day and age. 

Our skills and knowledge range from marketing, financing, engineering, accounting, biotechnology , to aquaponics and just about everything in between. We have both played vital roles in previous start-ups and have an amazing network.  In short we have what it takes to take Locals from an idea to reality. 


  Nadia Robinson | CEO 

Nadia has a life-long fascination with growing and helping others. She has played vital roles in launching three start-ups prior to Locals. She also has multiple years of greenhouse experience as well as other growing experience. She has degrees in Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship and Emerging Enterprises. She always wanted to start a company which combines doing something she loves while leaving a positive impact on the world. Coming from an entrepreneurial background, she started Locals to realize that vision.

 

   Louis Bookoff | CMO

Louis is a currently majoring in Entrepreneurship  and Emerging Enterprises and Accounting at the Whitman School of Management.  He has led various marketing campaigns for restaurants and a startup company. He has a passion for food and believes that everyone should have access to affordable healthy produce, which inspired him to join Locals. 

You've heard from us and now we'd love to hear from you.

Please let us know if you have any questions, comments or suggestions!

Email Us at info@localsgrowsmart.com

Please note that our team will try as hard as possible to answer any and all questions and comments that are left on the comments page but the easiest way to get immediate assistance is to email us at info@localsgrowsmart.com 


Don't forget to like and follow us for the latest information on all things Local!

Like Us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/localsorganicfood

Send us a tweet: @LocalsGrowSmart

(Quick note: We love hearing from backers,so feel free to email us ) 

     Share our campaign and help us serve you! 

GROW SMART                                                HAPPINESS GROWS

story:
Hi,

My name is Mr. Ameer. I am a children's book author. The book featured in this video is entitled "My First Million". The two children in the video are my daughter and son. They are very successful young entrepreneurs. I wrote the book to tell a wonderful story about a student remembering how the first million he ever received was not money but the loving kisses of his mother.

I also wrote it to give children, especially intercity children, a job where they can learn the basics of what it takes to start and run their own business. As a society we are losing too many of our children to destructive environments and non productive thinking. This book gives them an honest way to clean themselves up and learn entrepreneurial skills. In local areas around the country there are festivals and events going on all the time. What I do is take a small group of kids to these events and have them sell face to face with strangers. At first they are very nervous but I coach them on each sell and give them praise and advice. I don't intervene until after the sell. The children begin to develop social skills and strategies to meet their goal. At each event I give them a goal of 1 to as many as 20 books depending on what level they are. The two children in this video have goals of 20 or more books because they can consistently sell that many within a two hour span. We usually do not stay at an event longer than 4 hours and they do very well within that time span. 

I wholesale the books to the kids for $4 and they sell the books for $8 - $10. The lesson is to always double your money or more. 

You will be either purchasing the book, which is a great read to your child or purchasing at wholesale price to train kids in your local area. I have additional footage of the two children in the video where they are giving more information on their experiences and strategies that I will send to wholesale buyers. 

Thank you for your support and remember that part of being a good entrepreneur is having the right product or service. This book really does bring in $20/hr per child at most events and festivals, especially at family events.

If you need your book(s) fast please send me a comment! 

Visit us at www.mrameer.com for more information about our books.
